comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text:
Léonce Raffin wrote a biography of Anne de Gonzaga, Princess Palatine (1616-1684), goddaughter of the queen of France, and daughter of the duc de Nevers.  She first sided with the nobility in the Fronde but then aligned herself with the royal family.  She was instrumental in arranging the marriage between Elizabeth Charlotte "Liselotte", duchesse d'Orléans, (styled "Madame") and Philippe, duc d'Orléans, ("Monsieur") the brother of Louis XIV.  This book could have been relevant to research Raffin did on Anne de Gonzaga.
His works (some about Burgundy and Burgundians) seem to be published in the early 20th century--a little late for the handwriting, I agree, and certainly a bit after the fact if he was buried in 1864, unless these are reprints.

comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text: The Léonce Raffin buried in 1864 was an adolescent, and it sounds, from his eulogy, as if he might have died following an illness.  (I think there was a major outbreak of cholera in 1864; the beginning of the text mentions the significant number of deaths among the elderly.)

comment.author: 58558794@N07
comment.text: Wikipedia entry : In 1663-1664, Sorbière visited England, where he was inducted into the Royal Society. In 1664 he published an account of his stay, Relation d’un voyage en Angleterre, où sont touchées plusieurs choses, qui regardent l’estat des sciences, et de la religion. (L. Billaine: Paris), in which he offered his comments on how bad the food was, how bad the inns were and imputed to the Royal Society the intention of developing a library. This provoked Thomas Sprat (then spokesman for and historian of the Society) to publish Observations upon Monsieur de Sorbier's Voyage into England (London: 1665) as a reply to Sorbière's perceived insults against both English culture and the Society in particular. In order to avoid further international controversy, Sorbière was held under arrest for four months in France, and Charles II of England prohibited any further responses.

comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: well, i hope to do better than this: uk.answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20110222042119AAr... there are (at least) two mentions of a J. Barry Brown in library contexts: the first, from the University of California, mentions that their "Music Library was especially strengthened through the purchase of the J. Barry Brown Music Collection of some two hundred and fifteen items largely in the field of 18th century vocal and instrumental music published in England and Ireland. " content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb18700306&doc.view=fram... the second, from McMaster University, posts the following: "In the 1960s and 1970s when McMaster University was expanding and aspired to the status of being a research-intensive university, Dr. William Ready, University Librarian and Professor of Bibliography, with singular passion went out of his way to acquire archives and rare books. Shortly after he raised money to acquire the Russell archives at auction, Ready, for example, purchased the J. Barry Brown collection of 8,317 books and pamphlets, for £26,500. Brown's book collection, which weighed 17,500 pounds, focussed on the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Among other things it included first editions of Jane Austen's Northanger Abbey and Persuasion (1818), Emma (1816), and Mansfield Park (1814). Those four remarkable novels alone now have a combined market value above the price that Ready paid for the Brown collection. Writing to Brown on 24 January 1969, Ready rhapsodized: "The rare book room, where your collection will be housed, is taking shape almost daily, and amid all the mud and bulldozers, the snow and the ice, there seems to be hanging over the place a feeling that this purgatorial time will be over and, while heaven will not result, a place of light and beauty will arise out of the slime and mush." library.mcmaster.ca/archives/exhibitions/splendours/intro...

comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: per Antiquariaat Forum: the Comte Chandon de Briailles, whose bookplate ... "Au Conte Chandon de Briailles". This is most likely Raoul Chandon de Briailles (1850-1908), historian and wine merchant (founder of the Chandon de Briailles mark of champagne), part of whose rich library was bequeathed to the Médiathèque at Épernay. continuing the thought elsewhere... "20,000 items concerning the history of Epernay and wine, incunables, and books from the sixteenth to the nineteenth centuries--and part passed on through the family to his heirs Comtes Henri and François Chandon de Briailles." the libraries of comtes Henri & Francois Chandon de Briailles was sold at auction in Paris, on October 25, 2004, by Tajan auction(eers? / house?). Raoul apparently had some of his library bound in an armorial binding... often seen with his plate... this specimen is apparently his plate... "Henri" (i.e. Henry) has a variant bookplate: *see also*: Henry Chandon de Briailles

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Ms. leaf, probably from an antiphonary, containing texts and music from a Reimofficium (or rhythmical office) for the feast of St. Martha (29 July). Visible in this image are the antiphons for the second nocturn -- "Verbum bonum eructavit" (which ends "Multa plebis milia"), "Transfert montes in cor maris" and "Monte sancto solidata" -- with the titles of two of their associated psalms (Ps. 44(45), "Eructavit cor meum", and Ps. 45(46), "Deus noster refugium"). For full texts of this Reimofficium, see: Blume, Clemens, and Guido M. Dreves, eds. Historiae rhythmicae: Liturgische Reimofficien des Mittelalters. 7. Folge. Analecta hymnica medii aevi XXVIII. Leipzig: O.R. Reisland, 1898. P. 58-60. (Thanks to concordiadomi, above, for the initial pointer!)

comment.text: Ms. leaf, probably from an antiphonary, containing texts and music from a Reimofficium (or rhythmical office) for the feast of St. Martha (29 July). Visible in this image is a portion of the responsory for the first nocturn (the third respond, which begins "Fide lucet redimita" and ends "... fidei perfectio" and the verse "In hac lucet, qua germanus") followed by the "Gloria Patri"; a rubric indicates the beginning of the second nocturn and is followed by the first letters of its first antiphon, "Verbum bonum eructavit". For full texts of this Reimofficium, see: Blume, Clemens, and Guido M. Dreves, eds. Historiae rhythmicae: Liturgische Reimofficien des Mittelalters. 7. Folge. Analecta hymnica medii aevi XXVIII. comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Ex biblica. Altempsna. [Ms. ownership inscription of the Biblioteca Altempsiana. It was founded by the Austrian churchman Markus Sittikus von Hohenems, Cardinal Altemps (1531-1595), nephew of Pope Pius IV, at the Palazzo Altemps in Rome and expanded by his nephew Mark Sittich, Archbishop of Salzburg (1574-1619). (Both men are also known by the Italianized form of their name, Marco Sittico Altemps, Altemps being a calque of Hohenems.) The library was eventually absorbed into the Biblioteca vaticana. Established heading: Biblioteca altempsiana.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Upper board: one leaf of a ms. bifolium (recto visible), containing Latin glosses on Gregory's Decretals? Most entries open with the words "Nota quod"; the red-underlined headings appear to correspond to the opening word(s) of the chapter being glossed. Frame ruling visible; text written in brown ink in 2 columns of 36 lines (first line below top line of ruling) with red initials and underlines. In the left-hand column, the red-underlined headings appear to correspond to the opening words of lib. 2, tit. 27, cap. 11-15: C{onsangu}i[n]ei Cu{m ol}im C{um inter} C{ausam q}ue int[er] Q{uod ad consultationem?} In the left-hand column, the red-underlined headings appear to correspond to the opening words of lib. 2, tit. 27, cap. 16-20: Sicut nob[is] Cum su[per] [con]tro. Cum b[er]tholdus In causis Int[er] The text following the heading "Cum b[er]tholdus" can be found in the glossa ordinaria of the Decretals, lib. 2, tit. 27, cap. 18.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Lower board: one leaf of a ms. bifolium (verso visible), containing Latin glosses on Gregory's Decretals? Most entries open with the words "Nota quod"; the red-underlined headings appear to correspond to the opening word(s) of the chapter being glossed. Frame ruling visible; text written in brown ink in 2 columns of 36 lines (first line below top line of ruling) with red rubric, initials, paragraph marks, and underlines. In the left-hand column, the visible red-underlined headings correspond to the opening words of lib. 3, tit. 4, cap. 6-13: C{onsequente} De cet[er]o Ex parte Qualit[er] Int[er] q[ua]tuor Ex tue Tue Ex p[ar]te In the right-hand column, the first heading corresponds to the title of lib. 3, tit. 4, cap. 16: "Cum ad h[oc]". The next heading, "Clericos quida[m]," probably refers to cap. 17, which begins (in this edition, at least), "Clericos in ecclesiis tuae". The rubric "De p[re]bendis et dignitatibus" corresponds to the title of lib. 3, tit. 5, and the visible red-underlined headings which follow correspond to the opening words of the text of cap. 4-9: E{piscopus} Quia i[n] tantu[m] Cum tenea[mur] Refferente [sic] Maiorib[us] Relatu[m]

comment.author: 58880069@N07
comment.text: Apparently Silvaretia is the Latin form for the Italian: Salvarezza, Selvarezza, Servarezza, Silvarezza . Cf. this Google book. Salvarezza seems to be the most common form used for the name of a noble family in Genoa. The second name could be Ioannes in the Genitive form "Ioannis" (because I see a "s" at the end). I have problems with the third name because I see an "y" in the end, an ending for a Genitive form of something that ends in "us", (and Andreas ends in "ae" for Genitive: Andreae). So, I'm considering other possibilities; Andrelinus is a name that starts with "And" and ends in "us", but it's also very rare. Giovanni Antonio seems to be a far more popular combination of fore names in Italian. I also found evidence of a Giovanni “Silvaritia” di Bartolomeo, associated with a 1689 date in this doc. Possible name: Giovanni Antonio Salvarezza.

comment.author: 58654589@N08
comment.text: Dr. Baugh, College 1912; Ph.D. English, 1916; and Honorary Doctorate in 1961, Chaired the University of Pennsylvania Department of English, and received many accolades, including the Lindback Award for Distinguished Teaching. Dr. Baugh's scholarship is still much in use at the Penn Library—from his 1935 study of the history of the English language to his 1968 bibliography of Chaucer studies. www.library.upenn.edu/portal/Baugh/fund.html The New York Times -- Obituary Albert C. Baugh Is Dead; Noted Medieval Scholar 27 March 1981 Albert C. Baugh, who taught English at the University of Pennsylvania for almost half a century and was a distinguished medieval scholar, died Saturday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 90 years old and a resident of Philadelphia. Dr. Baugh was known for his writing on the English language and the literature and culture of the Middle Ages. He was the editor and a contributing author to ''A Literary History of England'' and also wrote, ''A History of the English Language.'' He was born in Philadelphia and attended the University of Pennsylvania, where he received both his master's and doctoral degrees. He began as a ''reader'' in the English department in 1912, and from 1946 to 1961, when he retired, he served as the Felix E. Schelling Memorial Professor of English. Dr. Baugh was president of the Modern Humanities Research Association of Cambridge, England, from 1948 to 1950, and president of the International Federation for Modern Languages and Literatures from 1960 to 1963. He also was a former president of the Fellows of Medieval Academy at Harvard University. He leaves his wife, the former Nita Scudder; and two sons, William of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., and Daniel of Ithaca, N.Y.

comment.text: Satire against Martin Luther, framed as a game of Bock (a popular contemporary card game).  "Bock" is also the German word for goat, hence the illustration.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Upper inscription: Hieronymus Sauler Eccl Mosbac: Pastor [Hieronymous Sauler (1639-1716), schoolmaster at Ansbach and pastor at Mosbach, according to this entry in the catalog of the Staats- und Universitätsbibliothek Hamburg. According to this transcription of the appendix of the Gedenck-, Stadt- und Huth-Buch (Chronik der Stadt Feuchtwangen), Sauler served as pastor of Mosbach from 1674 until his death.] Lower inscription: Theophili Pauli Christii Coburgensis [Gottlieb Paul Christ (1707-1786), professor, librarian and court functionary at Ansbach. In their finding aid Aldine Press Books at the Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center, The University of Texas at Austin (Austin: The Center, 1998), Craig W. Kallendorf and Maria X. Wells identify the ex-libris "Theophili Pauli Christi" as "Gottlieb Paul Christ (18th cent.), prof. at Anspach Gymnasium". According to his biographical entry in C.A. Baader, Lexikon Verstorbener Schrifsteller des 18. und 19. Jahrhunderts (Augsburg: Von Jenisch- und Stage'schen Buchhandlung, 1825), Bd. 2, T. 1, p. 22, Christ was born in Coburg but came to Ansbach in 1728 to take service with Freiherr von Seckendorff (probably Christoph Ludwig Freiherr von Seckendorff-Aberdar). He went abroad on several diplomatic missions and became the librarian for the Ansbacher Schlossbibliothek. (According to E.F.C. Oertel in Georg Ludwig Oeder der erste Rektor bei der Einweihung des neuen Gymnasiums in Ansbach am 12. Juni 1737 ... (Ansbach: Oertel, 1837) p. 54-55, he got the job in 1738; according to the Schlossbibliothek's history web page, he was the second librarian to be appointed.) In 1737 he was appointed professor at the gymnasium in Ansbach and published a number of works on historical subjects; he also continued to serve at court as a councillor. He has a VIAF entry here.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Penn Libraries copy bound in 1 early printed vellum leaf supplemented on upper board by a portion of another, possibly from a missal or lectionary (text of full leaf: gospel for Palm Sunday; text of partial leaf: gospel for Good Friday).

Folio? (leaf size ca. 360 x 270 mm.) printed in double columns; 32 lines to a full column; area of text: ca. 267 x 180 mm.; col. width: 85 mm. Capital strokes supplied in red ms.  Text of complete leaf: Matthew 26:28-26:47.  Text of partial leaf: John 18:9-10 (left-hand column) and John 18:17-19 (right-hand column).

[Probably not a folio Bible -- those seem generally to have more lines per page.  Almost certainly too big for a Book of Hours.]

comment.text: Ex libris Principissa Piccolominia Bibliotheca Slakoverdensis Scholarum Piarum [The library of the Piarist college in Schlackenwerth (now Ostrov, Czech Republic), founded in 1666 and disbanded in 1876. Cf. W. Sommer, Kurze Geschichte der Stadt Schlackenwerth in Verbindung mit dem Piaristen-Collegium (Schlackenwerth, 1866). According to this entry in the Yale Law Library Rare Books Blog, "[m]ajor donations to the library included the collection of Princess Maria Piccolomini" -- probably Maria Benigna Francisca Piccolomini (1635-1701), born Maria Benigna Francisca of Saxony, Angria and Westphalia, daughter of Julius Henry of Saxe-Lauenburg (1586-1665), who had property interests in Ostrov, and wife of Ottavio Piccolomini-Pieri, duca d’Amalfi (1599-1656), who campaigned there.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Median folio(?) [leaf size: 310 x 214 mm.], printed in double columns. Leaf A4r: 41 lines to a full column, plus headline ("Von der kunst cristi"); area of text: 246 (260) x 156 mm.; col. width: 73 mm. Two 2-line initial spaces, 1with visible guide-letter (initials supplied in red ms.). Spaces for 2 paragraph marks (supplied in red; section headings read: "Von sant Eütropio des königs von persia sune." and "Von san bartolomes dz er eins königs sun von siria sey gewesenn. vnd sich auch mit dem herrene bekümert hab."). (Capital strokes supplied in red.) With signature ("A iiij"); without foliation or catchword. Very possibly from Schatzbehalter der wahren Reichtümer des Heils by Stephan Fridolin, O.F.M., printed in Nuremberg by Anton Koberger on 8 November 1491 (ISTC is00306000). Cf. this image. This Christie's auction catalog entry gives the following description: "Median 2° (335 x 235 mm). Collation: a-z6 ab-ad6 ae8 A-Z6 Aa-Gg6 Hh10 (a1 blank, a2r prologues, a4v text, Hh9r colophon, Hh9v-10 blank). 354 leaves. 40 lines and headline, double column, printed guide-letters."

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Ex Bibliotheca Episcopatus Neostadiensis [Just noting some dissenting voices: One of these Beinecke copies of Valerij Maximi dictorum, & factorum memorabilium libri nouem (Argentorati : Ex aedibus Schurerianis, mense Iulio, ann. M.D.XIIII. [1514]) has the same inscription, identified as the library of the bishopric of Neustadt an der Haardt (now Neustadt an der Weinstrasse) in Germany, but that's in the diocese of Speyer. KBR has a copy of Theophylacti archiepiscopi Bulgariae in quatuor Euangelia enarrationes (Antuerpiae : apud Martinum Caesarem, 1531) also with this inscription and identifies it as Neuss, but Neuss is in the archdiocese of Cologne. (The KBR book also has a 16th-century Viennese provenance inscription.) I suspect both the Beinecke and KBR have misidentified "Episcopatus Neostadiensis" and that Wiener Neustadt is probably correct. For a shred of positive evidence, cf. this citation of "Roxas, Christophorus, Episcopus Neostadiensis" in Tabulae Codicum Manu Scriptorum Praeter Graecos et Orientales in Bibliotheca Palatina Vondobonensi Asservatorum (Vindobonae: Caroli Geroldi Filius, 1873) v. 6, p. 32 & 426, which certainly refers to Christoph de Rojas y Spinola, OFM, Bishop of Wiener-Neustadt from 1685-1695.]

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
Woodcut ("Sauritt des Papsts") after Lucas Cranach the Elder, used by Christian Rödinger the Elder of Magdeburg. According to I. Gobry, it is a reproduction of a Cranach woodcut (no. 6) in Martin Luther's 1545 polemic Abbildung des Bapstum (cf. Image de la papauté (Grenoble: Millon, 1997), p. 118). R.W. Scribner unpacks the symbolism of the image in the context of Luther's intent to "discredit papal plans for a General Council of the Church":
The pope rides on a sow, carrying a spiral of steaming excrement on his open palm. The Latin text at the top says this is how the pope holds a council in Germany. The German text states that the sow must allow itself to be ridden and spurred from both sides. There are two allusions here. Luther often spoke of Germany as the "papal sow", to be force-fed with papal lies for the pope's sole gain. There was also a popular riddle in circulation, and which appeared in print in 1541: "How do you ride a sow so that it does not bite? -- Put dung on your hand, and when the sow smells it, it will chase it and not bite the rider." The message, then, was that Germany may well seek a council from the pope, but all it could expect was lies and deceit. (Cf. For the Sake of Simple Folk: Popular Propaganda for the German Reformation (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1994), p. 82-83.)
The image may also have anti-Semitic undertones, recalling satirical depictions of Jews riding on pigs (cf. R.W. Scribner, Popular Culture and Popular Movements in Reformation Germany (London: Hambledon Press, 1987), p. 292).

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: For a thorough analysis of the Sauritt in anti-Semitic propaganda, see Birgit Wiedl, "Laughing at the Beast" in Laughter in the Middle Ages and Early Modern Times, ed. A. Classen (Berlin: De Gruyter, 2010), p. 323ff.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text:
D'oh! I'm used to depictions of Our Lady of Sorrows with her heart pierced by multiple swords (usually 7, representing her Seven Sorrows: the prophecy of Simeon, the flight into Egypt, the search for the boy Jesus when he remained behind in the Temple, encountering Jesus on the Way of the Cross, his crucifixion, his deposition and his burial). According to B. Heal, however, images of the Virgin pierced by a single sword were also common in 16th-century Germany, directly referencing Simeon's prophecy in Luke 2:34-35:
Et benedixit illis Simeon, et dixit ad Mariam matrem ejus: "Ecce positus est hic in ruinam et in resurrectionem multorum in Israël, et in signum cui contradicetur, et tuam ipsius animam pertransibit gladius ut revelentur ex multis cordibus cogitationes."
Cf. B. Heal, The Cult of the Virgin Mary in Early Modern Germany (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2007), p. 32, with illustration. See also M. Warner, Alone of All Her Sex (New York: Vintage Books, 1983), p. 206-223.

comment.text:
Penn Libraries copy bound in early full blind-tooled pig over beveled and indented wooden boards; 3 raised bands on spine; blind-tooled spine panels with evidence of ms. in panel at head of spine; 2 leather and metal clasps with metal catchplates; all edges blue.

Upper board (pictured here) has central panel with figures of Faith (holding crucifix and chalice with host) and Hope (hands clasped in prayer, looking at small figure of God in clouds above) seated face to face within an oval frame with motto: IMPETRAT IMA FIDES CHRISTO QVAM DANTE SATEM EX SPES ANIMOSA SOLET (i.e. Impetrat alma fides Christo quam Dante salutem expectare soror spes animosa solet), the whole in a rectangular frame with figures of the 4 cardinal virtues at corners, each with banner.  Clockwise from top left: IVSTI (Justitia), PRV (Prudentia), TEMP (Temperantia), and FORT (Fortitudo).

comment.text:
"Marggretten zu Baden" might refer to Klosterstift St. Margarethen in Waldkirch, ten miles northeast of Freiburg im Breisgau.  Cf. another inscription in this book dated "1570. Friburgi":

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/58558794@N07/5616070384/]
Klosterstift St. Margarethen was home to a community of canons from 1437 until secularization in 1806; before that it was Kloster St. Margarethen, a nunnery established ca. 915 whose last abbess died in 1430.  Waldkirch is located in the historically Baden part of the state of Baden-Württemberg.  (NB: Elissa, if female, can't be a canon, but might live in the neighborhood.)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: I think the answer to the "Which monks?" question depends on either dating the ms. or finding out what kind of ownership inscriptions the Cistercians use(d). Prior to 1806, "Monasterium Brigantinum" would be the Austrian Benedictine house, absolutely: the community was founded ca. 611, possibly as a double monastery, but went Benedictine in 1079; it was secularized and the library evidently dispersed in 1806. The subsequent Cistercian foundation doesn't take up residence there until 1854; previously (1227-1841), they were a going concern in Wettingen, Switzerland, until the cantonal authorities shut them down in the Argauerklosterstreit. I'm not sure they would have called themselves "Monasterium Brigantinum" once arriving there -- their Latin name appears to be "Abbatia Territorialis Beatae Mariae Virginis de Maris Stella et de Augia Majore" with the short forms "Augia Major" and "Augia Brigantina." I do find a couple of other instances of this ownership inscription in sale catalogs: Martyan Lan has an incunable copy of Boethius's De consolatione philosophiae for sale with an "Ex Bibliotheca Monasterii Brigantini" inscription identified as 17th-century Benedictine. Christie's has another incunable, Johannes Nider's Tractatus de morali lepra, with the same inscription similarly called 17th-century Benedictine. On balance, I'd guess both from the form of the name and the testimony of these learned booksellers that we've got the a book from the library of the Benedictines of Meherau Abbey. I can't tell if this is 17th-century handwriting, though (looks awfully legible for that, despite the "-ij" :-)

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Re: Mehrerau Abbey: this website notes that it was established in 610 "[o]riginally for nuns by St. Gall. 1079 monks added or replace nuns. Reformed 1089. Founders S. Columban and S. Gall." Thus its tenure as a possible double monastery postdates its founding by several centuries.

comment.text: transcription: "Bibliotheek der Vereen[igde]. Doopsg[ezinde]. Gemeente te Amsterdam" and "Bibliotheek der Amst[erdamer]. Doopsg[ezinde]. Gemeente verkocht" (verkocht = sold) this library seems to form a highly influential part of the holdings of the University of Amsterdam library special collections, and is now called: Bibliotheek en Archief van de Vereenigde Doopsgezinde Gemeente te Amsterdam. heading(?): "Universiteit van Amsterdam. Bibliotheek" some info.: Amsterdam Mennonite Library (Bibliotheek en Archief van de Vereenigde Doopsgezinde Gemeente te Amsterdam). The The foundation for the very rich collection owned by the congregation at Amsterdam and placed at the service of the Amsterdam Theological Seminary students was laid by the preacher of the Lamist congregation and also a doctor of medicine at Amsterdam, Johannes Reyers, in the gift of his library to the church in 1680. Other contributions followed. In 1801 the library of the Amsterdam Zonist congregation was added, and later the library of the Utrecht congregation, which it had received by bequest from the historian Marten Schagen. In 1833 the library was enriched by a gift by Govert Jan van Rijswijk containing many rare books on Mennonite history. When Samuel Muller became professor of the seminary the library was greatly expanded. The expenses for this were defrayed in part by the sale of the equipment of a physical laboratory of the seminary and by the large contributions made by the members of the Amsterdam congregation during those years. The library contained not only Mennonitica. In 1768 Peter Fontein, a minister at Amsterdam, bequeathed to the library a valuable collection of books in the field of ancient languages. In 1894 it received as a gift the unique collection of the late minister Loosjes on Pascal and Vinet. In 1946 the late minister Cornelis Nijdam willed to the library a number of works by and about Schleiermacher. A systematic catalog with a Latin foreword by Gerrit Hesselink was printed in 1793. In 1854 the first part of a new catalog was published, containing titles of general theological works. In 1888 the second part was published, drawn up by Jacob Gijsbert de Hoop Scheffer. It contained (a) Teleiobaptistica (Mennonitica); (b) Greek and Latin classics, philology, and other works. A new catalog of Mennonitica alone appeared in 1919 prepared by Jan Gerrit Boekenoogen. Among the greatest treasures of the library are the old writings of Menno Simons, David Joris,Dirk Philips, the old martyr literature (an almost complete set of the editions of the Offer des Heeren), a large rare collection of small writings on the Lammerenkrijg anda large collection of Mennonite hymnals. A very valuable supplement to the collection of printed works are the archives of the Amsterdam congregation. Besides many letters and documents important to Mennonite history there are the membership records of the Waterlander congregation of the period 1612-1673, of the Flemish 1625-1670; of the Lamist and Toren congregation after the union with the Waterlanders 1668-1829; and of the Zonist congregation 1686-1801. In addition a great number of letters from and to Amsterdam, also the records and documents of the various Societeits and the archives of the Commissie voor Buitenlandse Nooden containing many letters and reports concerning the persecution and emigration of the Swiss Mennonites to America. For this archival material a catalog prepared by the archivist de Hoop Scheffer was published in two parts (1883 and 1884). The entire catalog contains 7,521 numbers. The library was later moved to Singel 452, in a house which was bought by the congregation as early as 1633, but the library was not brought here until 1839, after it was reorganized. In 2006 the library was part of the University Library at the University of Amsterdam. Bibliography Catalogus der werken over de Doopsgezinden en hunne geschiedenis: aanwezig in de bibliotheek der Vereenigde Doopsgezinde Gemeente te Amsterdam. Amsterdam: J. H. de Bussy, 1919. Hoop Scheffer, J. G. de. Inventaris der archiefstukken berustende bij de Vereenigde Doopsgezinde Gemeente te Amsterdam, 2 vols. Amsterdam: Kerkeraad dier Gemeente, 1883-1884. Church History Collections [at the University of Amsterdam] www.uba.uva.nl/special_collections/overview.cfm/AFCF61B8-... The Church History Collections comprise early and modern printed works, manuscripts, prints, brochures, picture carriers and sound recordings relating to theology and church history in general, and to the history of Dutch Protestantism and the Radical Reformation in particular. Apart from its own extensive collection, the core of the Church History Collections is formed by the loans from the library of the Evangelical Lutheran Seminary, and from the Amsterdam libraries of the United Mennonite Congregation, the Remonstrant Congregation, the Reformed Evangelical Lutheran Congregation and the Begijnhof Foundation. Main focus Dutch church history of the 16th to the 19th centuries, focusing on: *The history of Jansenism, the history of the Miracle of Amsterdam. *The history of Lutheranism (early and modern scholarly editions of Luther and Melanchthon, Luther bibles, hymnbooks, sermons). *The history of Anabaptism and the Mennonite movement from ca. 1520 to the present day (martyr books, bibles, hymnbooks, pamphlets and tracts by advocates and opponents). *The history of Remonstrantism (nearly complete collection of pamphlets and tracts by leaders and opponents of Remonstrantism, prints). *The history of spiritualism and heterodoxy (printed work by e.g. Sebastian Franck, Caspar Schwenckfeld, Hendrik Jansz Barrefelt [= Hiël], Hendrik Niclaes, Adam Pastor, David Joris, Faustus Socinus, Jacob Böhme, Antoinette Bourignon). *Bibles, psalm books and spiritual hymnbooks, works printed in Amsterdam in the field of religion, devotional literature and prints. Reading Room Church History Collections / Mennonite Reading Room The Mennonite Reading Room is located in the University Library Special Collections at the Oude Turfmarkt 129. The reading room has been set up for the collection of the United Mennonite Congregation of Amsterdam. It also incorporates the Mennonite Documentation Centre covering the period: 1800 to the present day. Besides the reference library containing books relevant to the history of Anabaptism, the most important journals and reference books on the history of the Reformation are also placed here in open access.

comment.text: Depicting Arion: "A Greek poet of the 7th cent BC, famous for his skill on the lyre. He was once threatened with robbery and murder by the crew of a boat in which he was a passenger. he jumped overboard and was carried safely to shore on the back of a dolphin that had been attracted by the sound of his music. He is shown riding on a dolphin holding either a lyre or, in Italian Renaissance pictures, a lira da braccio, a bowed instrument of the viol type. He may wear a laurel wreath." James Hall, Dictionary of Subjects and Symbols in Art

comment.author: 58880069@N07
comment.text:
I personally think the inscription is a Genitive form ( "y' at end) of the personal name "Nicolay" , which appears in the inscription on the title page. The Nicolay family is a European noble family of the Ancien Régime with its roots in the south of France at the early part of the 14th Century. 

Nikolaischule would have used the German variant of Nicholas, which is Nikolaus or Nikolai. Plus the Latin form of the school is Schola Nikolaitana and the Genitive form would end in "ae".

comment.text: OK, I changed it back to Nicolay ... but we are again left with figuring out what comes after.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: Edith Barbara Tranter was secretary to W. T. H. Howe (1874-1939), president of the American Book Company in Cincinnati, and subsequently administrator of his estate.  She appears herself to have collected books and mss.; her library was sold at auction by Parke-Bernet on March 18, 1952.

comment.author: 58584977@N05
comment.text: One of two men: Sir David Salomons (1797-1873), 1st Baronet; financier and politician, the first Jewish Sheriff of the City of London and Lord Mayor of London, and one of the first two Jewish MPs to serve in the House of Commons. Sir David Salomons (1851-1925), 2nd Baronet (nephew of the first Sir David); professional jurist and amateur electrical engineer.

comment.author: 58880069@N07
comment.text: Colonel the Honourable Fulke Greville Howard, d. 1846. "Hon. Fulke Greville Howard was the son of Clotworthy Upton, 1st Baron Templetown and Elizabeth Boughton. He married Mary Howard, daughter of Richard Howard and Frances Howard, on 9 July 1807. He died on 4 March 1846, without issue. Hon. Fulke Greville Howard was baptised with the name of Fulke Greville Upton. His name was legally changed to Fulke Greville Howard." Cf. www.thepeerage.com/p6288.htm
